thread.title: In 3Q15, Citigroup’s Stock Is Cheaper than the Financial Sector - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: In 3Q15, Citigroup’s Stock Is Cheaper than the Financial Sector - Yahoo Finance

author: Rebecca Keats
title: In 3Q15, Citigroup’s Stock Is Cheaper than the Financial Sector - Yahoo Finance
text:
What to Watch for When Citigroup Reports Its 3Q15 Earnings 
( Continued from Prior Part )
Analysts expect upside in the stock Since the beginning of 2015, shares of Citigroup (C) have performed in line with the US financial sector, represented by the Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLF). Year-to-date, XLF has lost 6.9%, and Citigroup has generated returns of -6.9%. Additionally, XLF invests 0.35% of its portfolio in Citigroup.
On October 9, 2015, Citigroup’s stock closed at $51.38. With an average consensus price target of $63.89 and a median target estimate of $65, it is still at a whopping discount of 21% to analyst expectations. This suggests that Wall Street is upbeat about the stock despite the fact that it has been hurt by low interest rates and global weakness.

This trend is also evident if we look at the ratings on the stock. Among the 35 analysts following the stock, 30 have assigned “buy” ratings. Shares of Citigroup have received two “sell” ratings and have been currently assigned three “hold” ratings. Recently, analysts at Credit Suisse and Jefferies upgraded the stock to “buy.” If the 3Q15 earnings beat analysts’ expectations, we could see some of these hold ratings converted into further buys
However, it must be noted that the estimated earnings per share (or EPS) has been revised downward in 22 instances by research brokerages in the past four weeks and upward in just one instance.
Valuations Shares of Citigroup (C) trade at a price-to-book multiple of 0.75x while the average price-to-book multiple for banks in the XLF ETF is 1.16x. Citigroup is among the cheapest large-cap banks that form part of the XLF portfolio.

Citigroup’s large-cap peers Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), and the giant Goldman Sachs (GS) are trading at price-to-book multiples of 1.60x, 1.06x, and 1.01x, respectively.
